timeline.bodyText: If you store the InstanceHandle you can use it later to destroy a @Dependent bean correctly. See io.quarkus.arc.InstanceHandle.close().
timeline.author: mkouba

replies.bodyText: We can't really mock @dependent beans anyway.
replies.author: stuartwdouglas

replies.bodyText: Hm... Here we aren't storing the references, just using them to check and then obtain the bean. So we don't need to close them anywhere, no?
replies.author: geoand

replies.bodyText:
We can't really mock @dependent beans anyway.

Ah, that's correct. For @Dependent it would fail later when we try to install the mock by means of QuarkusMock.

So we don't need to close them anywhere, no?

It's ok for normal scoped beans and @Singleton. Nok for @Dependent.
replies.author: mkouba

replies.bodyText: Ah, now I see what your concern was! So yeah, no @Dependent - no problem :)
replies.author: geoand

timeline.bodyText: Since these are not CDI injection points it could happen that ArC will consider the resolved beans removable. Maybe we should handle this use case and mark them unremovable?
timeline.author: mkouba

replies.bodyText:
Like @stuartwdouglas said, if the bean has been removed, mocking won't change anything, so how would the user see the results of the their test?
I don't think this scenario is actually possible.
It's likely I think that if normally the bean would be removed in the prod app, the user would be injecting some other bean into the test to check the effect of the mock, thus making the mock unremovable.
replies.author: geoand

timeline.author: mkouba

replies.bodyText: Hm, maybe it's not a good idea. The injection points can be reused and allow us to mark the beans unremovable. Another idea - if we do @Inject @MockBean the client proxies will be injected first and we could wrap it afterwards. @MockBean is ignored by ArC but allows CreateMockitoMocksCallback to wrap the stuff. The advantage of this approach would be (1) no need to mark the beans unremovable, (2) no need to hold the instance handles and destroy them correctly.
replies.author: mkouba

replies.bodyText: Let me think about it and get back to you tomorrow :)
replies.author: geoand

replies.bodyText: Feel free to ping me to discuss the API ;-)
replies.author: mkouba

replies.bodyText: If a bean is removable then then mocking it would have no effect anyway.
replies.author: stuartwdouglas

replies.bodyText:
@mkouba if we do @Inject @MockBean in the test, then how would the user control the mocks?
My idea about @MockBean is that it should just be a Mockito mock that users already know how to handle without having to do anything else.  If we add @Inject in the mix, won't that complicate the mock usage on the user side?
replies.author: geoand

replies.bodyText:
If a bean is removable then then mocking it would have no effect anyway.

If a bean is removable then a null would be injected or an exception would be thrown - depends on the CreateMockitoMocksCallback impl. My point is that right now you can test a bean in a @QuarkusTest even if it would be normally removed in production because test class is considered a bean.

if we do @Inject @MockBean in the test, then how would the user control the mocks?

Like I said - the client proxies could be injected by ArC and then wrapped in the CreateMockitoMocksCallback and the wrapped mocks could be set back to the fields. So you would do Mockito.when(messageService.getMessage()).thenReturn("hi") like you do now.
replies.author: mkouba
geoand

replies.bodyText: You're probably right. It's a bit confusing though. We should probably add some docs and explain the intention...
replies.author: mkouba

replies.bodyText: Yes of course, I haven't added any docs yet but I absolutely plan to do so.
replies.author: geoand

timeline.message:
Add support for @MockBean

This allows users to easily combine Mockito with
Quarkus mocks without having to use anything
more than the @MockBean annotation

Add support for @InjectMock

Quarkus mocks without having to use anything
more than the @InjectMock annotation
